summary: An educational video lecture exploring the Big Bang theory, the expansion of the universe, and key scientific discoveries.

events_list.video_caption: The video opens with a black screen that transitions to a stunning view of Saturn, showcasing its rings and the vastness of space. The scene then shifts to a contact information screen featuring Professor Jim Caffey, with his email, social media handles, and a blurred image of himself. Following this, a title screen introduces '10-Minute Astronomy with Professor Jim Caffey,' Episode 45, Chapter 29, 'The Big Bang.' The video then displays an image of Comet Hyakutake from March 20, 1995, alongside a picture of a telescope at Kitt Peak National Observatory. The scene transitions to a person wearing headphones, seated in a room with a couch, a chair, and various decorations, including a painting of a red object on water. The person appears to be speaking, with the word 'ASTRONOMY' displayed above them. The video then shows a PowerPoint slide titled 'Chapter 29 The Big Bang,' featuring the cover of 'Introduction to Astronomy.' The final frame presents an image of the James Webb Space Telescope, with a caption explaining its features and purpose. Throughout the video, the person remains seated, occasionally gesturing with their hands, and the background remains consistent, featuring the same room and decorations.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip commences with dramatic and building orchestral music evoking a sense of grandiosity.  A male speaker is then introduced who sounds like a Professor, stating, "Hello this is professor Jim Caffey and today we are doing the next to last lecture in our 30 chapter series called 10 minute astronomy for the Open Stacks astronomy free textbook." He then introduces chapter 29 which, "is called the Big Bang are you ready? Okay, here we go." The speech continues in an informative manner stating, "Prepare to have your mind blown. Our space telescope of the future is almost here." The music is suddenly reintroduced and overtakes all speech.

events_list.video_caption: The video features a slide from a presentation, showcasing an illustration of the James Webb Space Telescope, labeled "FIGURE 29.1" at the top left corner. The telescope is depicted with its gold-colored primary mirror and a silver sunshade, set against a black background. Below the illustration, there is a caption that reads: "Space Telescope of the Future. This drawing shows the James Webb Space Telescope, which is currently planned for launch in 2018. The silver sunshade shadows the primary mirror and science instruments. The primary mirror is 6.5 feet (21.5 feet) in diameter. Before and during launch, the mirror will be folded up. After the telescope is placed in orbit, ground controllers will command it to unfold the mirror petals. To see distant galaxies whose light has been shifted to long wavelengths, the telescope will carry several instruments for taking infrared images and spectra. (credit: modification of work by NASA)." The slide also includes the "openstax" logo at the top right corner. In the bottom right corner of the frame, a person is visible, seemingly engaged in a discussion or presentation, wearing a green shirt and gesturing with their hands. The background of the slide is white, and the overall setting appears to be an educational or informative presentation environment.
events_list.audio_caption: A male speaker begins by discussing the launch of something in late 2019 to French Guiana, noting it will be far from Earth, unlike the Hubble. He mentions it will be bigger and more complex.

events_list.video_caption:
The video begins with a slide titled "FIGURE 29.2" featuring two black and white photographs. The first photo, labeled (a), shows Albert Einstein in a 1921 photograph, dressed in a suit and tie, standing in front of a chalkboard with mathematical equations. The second photo, labeled (b), depicts Edwin Hubble working at the Mt. Wilson Observatory, seated and operating a large telescope. The slide includes a caption that reads "Einstein and Hubble," with descriptions for each photograph. The OpenStax logo is visible in the top right corner, and a small inset in the bottom right corner shows a person in a room, possibly a presenter or instructor.

The video then transitions to another slide titled "FIGURE 29.3," which displays a grid of ten images arranged in two rows. The top row shows galaxies with arrows pointing to supernovae, while the bottom row shows the same galaxies before or after the supernovae exploded. The caption below the images reads "Five Supernovae and Their Host Galaxies," with additional text explaining that the top row shows each galaxy and its supernova, and the bottom row shows the galaxies before or after the supernovae exploded. The OpenStax logo remains in the top right corner, and the inset of the presenter or instructor is still visible in the bottom right corner.

The video continues with the same slide titled "FIGURE 29.3," displaying the grid of ten images of galaxies and supernovae. The caption below the images remains the same, explaining the content of the images. The OpenStax logo is still visible in the top right corner, and the inset of the presenter or instructor is still visible in the bottom right corner.

The video then transitions to another slide titled "FIGURE 29.4," which features a diagram illustrating the changes in the rate of expansion of the universe since its beginning 13.8 billion years ago. The diagram shows a timeline with labels for "Accelerating expansion," "Slowing expansion," and "Farthest supernova," with arrows indicating the direction of time. The caption below the diagram reads "Changes in the Rate of Expansion of the Universe Since Its Beginning 13.8 Billion Years Ago," explaining that the diagram shows how the expansion of the universe has changed over time, with periods of acceleration and deceleration. The OpenStax logo is visible in the top right corner, and the inset of the presenter or instructor is still visible in
events_list.audio_caption: The clip begins with a male speaker introducing the names "Einstein and Hubble." He continues with a description of a supernova and its host galaxy, explaining that a supernova involves a star "completely blowing itself apart" and becoming "brighter than the galaxy it's in combined," expressing awe.

events_list.video_caption: The video features a man seated at a desk, wearing a green shirt, and gesturing with his hands while explaining a scientific concept. In the background, a large diagram titled "FIGURE 29.4" from OpenStax is displayed, illustrating the changes in the rate of expansion of the universe since its beginning 13.8 billion years ago. The diagram shows a timeline with labels such as "Accelerating expansion," "Slowing expansion," and "Farthest supernova," along with a visual representation of the universe's expansion over time. The man appears to be discussing the diagram, pointing to different sections and explaining the concepts related to the universe's expansion, including the influence of gravity and dark energy. The setting is an indoor environment, likely a classroom or a study area, with a focus on the educational content being presented. The video maintains a consistent visual theme, with the man's gestures and the diagram serving as the primary elements of the narrative.
events_list.audio_caption: A male speaker starts describing a graph and explains that "over time, the expansion of the universe has been changing." His tone is informative and explanatory. He adds that the further back in time you look, the more distant galaxies move away from us with a high velocity, some as fast as 40 to 50% of the speed of light. He contrasts this with closer objects that don't move as quickly.

events_list.video_caption:
The video begins with a slide titled "FIGURE 29.5" featuring an image of the Globular Cluster 47 Tucanae, a dense collection of stars in the southern sky. The slide includes a caption explaining that this cluster is the second-brightest globular cluster in the night sky, containing hundreds of thousands of stars, and is among the oldest objects in our galaxy. The image is credited to NASA, ESA, and the Hubble Heritage (STScI/AURA)/ESA/Hubble Collaboration. The slide is part of an educational presentation, as indicated by the "openstax" logo in the top right corner. The presenter, visible in the bottom right corner, is wearing a green shirt and appears to be explaining the content of the slide.

The video then transitions to another slide titled "FIGURE 29.6," which showcases the European Extremely Large Telescope (E-ELT) under construction in Chile. The slide includes a height chart on the left side, ranging from 20 meters to 140 meters, and a photograph of the telescope's structure alongside the Colosseum in Rome for scale. The caption explains that the E-ELT, with its 39-meter diameter, is designed to observe very distant galaxies and understand their formation when the universe was young. The slide is also part of the educational presentation, as indicated by the "openstax" logo. The presenter, still visible in the bottom right corner, continues to explain the content of the slide, maintaining a consistent educational atmosphere throughout the video.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip starts with a male speaker describing something as "beautiful" and a "globular cluster" called "47 Tucanae". This is followed by an indistinct sound, possibly a movement or rustling noise.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a man sitting in front of a computer screen, wearing a green shirt and glasses, with a focused expression. The screen displays an image of the European Extremely Large Telescope (E-ELT) under construction in Chile, alongside the Colosseum in Rome, with a height scale on the left. The text explains the E-ELT's purpose in observing distant galaxies and understanding their formation. The scene transitions to a diagram labeled "FIGURE 29.7," illustrating the concept of expansion and redshift using two orange balloons, one smaller and one larger, with a wavy line inside each. The accompanying text describes how an elastic surface's expansion stretches light waves, resulting in a redshift. The video then shifts to another diagram labeled "FIGURE 29.8," depicting four possible models of the universe: decelerating, coasting, and accelerating universes, with a yellow square marking the present. The text explains the Hubble constant and the different rates of expansion for each model. Throughout the video, the man remains seated in front of the computer screen, with the background consistently showing a room with a desk and computer equipment. The video concludes with the man still in front of the screen, which now displays the diagram of the four possible models of the universe.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio starts with a male speaker describing and comparing the size of telescopes to the Coliseum, expressing amazement with a "Wow, they're huge." He continues explaining an analogy using a balloon and galaxies, then mentions raisin bread from previous chapters. He says that things will be getting tough, and states that there are four possible models of the universe. The audio ends by mentioning decelerating and closed or open systems.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a slide titled "FIGURE 29.8" from OpenStax, featuring a diagram illustrating four possible models of the universe: decelerating, coasting, and accelerating universes. The diagram uses a series of colorful, cone-shaped graphs to represent the expansion of the universe over time, with the yellow square marking the present. The accompanying text explains the concept of the Hubble constant and the different models of the universe's expansion. The scene transitions to another slide titled "FIGURE 29.10," showcasing the Hubble Ultra-Deep Field image, which displays a vast number of galaxies in various colors. The text describes the image's significance in understanding the universe's expansion and the redshift of galaxies. The video then shifts to a black-and-white photograph of Abbe Georges Lemaître, a Belgian cosmologist, with a caption detailing his contributions to the study of the universe's expansion and the Big Bang theory. The final slide, titled "FIGURE 29.12," features a composite image of George Gamow and collaborators, with a caption explaining the concept of 'ylem' and its relation to the Big Bang theory. The video concludes with a slide showing a group of men in suits, with one man emerging from a bottle labeled 'YLEM,' symbolizing the origin of the universe. The text explains the connection between the bottle and the Big Bang theory, as well as the inspiration behind a musical piece called 'Ylem' by composer Karlheinz Stockhausen. Throughout the video, the background remains consistent with a white slide and black text, while the images and captions provide educational insights into cosmology and the universe's expansion.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio features a single male speaker with a slightly elevated tone. He discusses concepts related to cosmology, including the possibility of "coasting along" or an "accelerating universe". He mentions the Hubble Ultra-Deep Field and notes two historical figures: Lemaitre, a Belgian cosmologist who predicted Hubble's Law, and George Gamow, who considered the physics of the Big Bang.

events_list.video_caption:
The video features a man in a green shirt seated in front of a computer screen, which displays a series of educational diagrams related to the Big Bang theory. Initially, the screen shows a graph titled "FIGURE 29.13," illustrating the temperature of the universe over time since the Big Bang, with annotations indicating various stages such as "Earliest era," "Radiation," "Protons and neutrons form," and "Galaxies form." The graph uses a color gradient from red to green to represent temperature changes, with the horizontal axis labeled "Time Elapsed since the Big Bang (seconds)" and the vertical axis labeled "Cosmic Radiation Temperature (K)." Below the graph, a caption explains that the diagram shows how the temperature of the universe varies with time as predicted by the standard model of the Big Bang, noting that both temperature and time scales change over vast ranges.

The video then transitions to another diagram titled "FIGURE 29.15," which compares the Cosmic Microwave Background and Cosmic Components. This diagram features two inverted cones, one labeled "Big Bang" and the other "Present," with the left cone showing a gradient from red to black and the right cone showing a gradient from blue to white. The caption below explains that early in the universe, photons were scattered off charged particles and could not travel far without colliding, but as the universe expanded and cooled, photons could travel freely. It also notes that water droplets in Earth's atmosphere scatter light more efficiently than air molecules, which is why vision is blocked by clouds.

Throughout the video, the man appears to be explaining the diagrams, gesturing towards the screen to emphasize key points. The background remains consistent, with the focus on the educational content displayed on the computer screen. The video maintains an informative and educational atmosphere, with the man's gestures and explanations complementing the visual aids to enhance understanding of the Big Bang theory and related concepts.
events_list.audio_caption: A male speaker begins in an informative tone, stating that the universe's temperature has cooled. He explains that we can measure the temperature of the edge of the universe using cosmic background radiation, noting it's only a few degrees Kelvin, many hundreds of degrees below zero. He specifies the number as about 2.73 Kelvin. The audio ends with a "hm" sound.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a black and white photograph of two men, Robert Wilson and Arno Penzias, standing in front of a large horn-shaped antenna. They are dressed in suits and appear to be smiling, with the background showing the antenna and some trees. The text on the slide reads "FIGURE 29.16" and provides a caption explaining that the photo was taken in 1978 after they received the Nobel Prize in physics for discovering cosmic background radiation. The scene then transitions to a colorful slide displaying a graph titled "FIGURE 29.17" with a curve representing the intensity of cosmic background radiation as a function of wavelength. The caption below the graph explains that the solid line shows the expected intensity for a blackbody at 2.73 K, and the boxes represent measurements by COBE's instruments, with a perfect fit. The video concludes with the same graph and caption, emphasizing the significance of the data presented. Throughout the video, the OpenStax logo is visible in the top right corner, and a small inset in the bottom right corner shows a person in a green shirt, possibly the presenter, gesturing as they explain the content.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a male speaker identifying Robert Wilson and Arno Penzias standing in front of the Bell Labs horn-shaped antenna, from which they accidentally discovered the cosmic background radiation. He states that they received their Nobel Prize in physics for it and mentions the measured radiation is 2.73 Kelvin. The speaker speaks in a factual and somewhat formal tone.

events_list.video_caption: The video features a man in a green shirt seated in front of a computer screen, presenting scientific information. Initially, the screen displays Figure 29.17, illustrating the cosmic background radiation with a graph showing brightness against wavelength, accompanied by a caption explaining the significance of the data. The man appears engaged, likely explaining the graph's details. The scene then transitions to Figure 29.18, which compares observations from three satellites used to measure the cosmic microwave background (CMB). This figure includes images of the satellites and a detailed map of the CMB, with a caption providing context about the data's importance. The man continues to speak, gesturing towards the screen, emphasizing the information presented. The video maintains a consistent educational atmosphere, with the man actively engaging with the audience through his presentation.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip starts with a male speaker stating that an instrument in space called "COBE" measured something. He explains that the instrument, called the Cosmic Origins Background Explorer, saw "some smoothness to the universe" in temperature but also "inconsistencies."

events_list.video_caption: The video features a man in a casual setting, likely a home or office, with a whiteboard or screen displaying educational content about the universe. Initially, the screen shows a diagram titled "FIGURE 29.19" with three types of space curvature: spherical, flat, and hyperbolic, each represented by a grid on a sphere, a flat plane, and a saddle-shaped surface, respectively. The man, dressed in a dark shirt, appears to be explaining the concept, gesturing towards the diagrams. The text below the diagrams discusses the density of matter and energy determining the geometry of space, with implications for the universe's fate. The scene transitions to another diagram titled "FIGURE 29.20," comparing Cosmic Microwave Background (CMB) observations with possible models of the universe, showing colorful maps and a grid representation of space curvature. The man continues to explain, pointing at the new diagrams. Finally, the screen displays "FIGURE 29.21," a pie chart titled "Composition of the Universe," illustrating the proportions of dark matter, dark energy, and ordinary matter. The man elaborates on the content, emphasizing the dominance of dark matter and energy. Throughout the video, the man's expressions and gestures suggest an engaging and informative presentation, with the educational content evolving from space curvature to the universe's composition.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio starts with an expression of interest. A male speaker ponders how the space of the universe could be shaped, questioning if it might be spherical, flat, or hyperbolic. He then wonders what the universe is comprised of, mentioning dark stuff. A male voice continues speaking, but what he is saying is not clear.

events_list.video_caption: The video features a presentation slide titled "FIGURE 29.21 Composition of the Universe," which includes a pie chart and accompanying text. The pie chart illustrates the composition of the universe, with dark energy making up 68%, dark matter 27%, and ordinary matter 5%. The slide also contains images and descriptions of dark matter and dark energy, along with a diagram of an atom. The text explains that only 5% of the universe's mass and energy is ordinary matter, with hydrogen and helium being the most common elements. The remaining 95% consists of dark matter and dark energy, which have not been detected in earthbound laboratories. The slide is branded with the "openstax" logo. In the background, a person is visible, seemingly engaged in a discussion or presentation, wearing a green shirt and gesturing with their hands. The setting appears to be an educational or professional environment, with a focus on conveying information about the universe's composition.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a male speaker discussing cosmology, stating that "in the observable universe, only 5% is the stuff we can actually see" like "stars, galaxies, planets, superclusters, all that stuff." The tone is informative and slightly conversational.

events_list.video_caption: The video features a person seated at a desk, wearing a green shirt, and speaking to the camera. The background is a whiteboard with various diagrams and text related to the composition of the universe. The first diagram, titled "FIGURE 29.21 Composition of the Universe," shows a pie chart with sections labeled "Dark matter 27%," "Dark energy 68%," and "Ordinary matter 5%." Accompanying text explains that only 5% of the universe's mass and energy is ordinary matter, while dark matter and dark energy make up the remaining 95%. The second diagram, titled "FIGURE 29.22 Changing Estimate of the Content of the Universe," displays three pie charts representing the universe's content in the 1970s, 1980s, and 1990s, with labels such as "Ordinary dark matter," "Exotic dark matter," and "Dark energy." The text below the diagrams discusses the evolving understanding of the universe's content over time. The person appears to be explaining these concepts, gesturing occasionally with their hands. The video maintains a consistent educational atmosphere, focusing on the diagrams and the presenter's explanations.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip begins with a male speaker discussing dark matter, stating that it comprises "27%" and dark energy comprises "two-thirds" of the universe's composition. He notes that we can detect it but not see it, making it difficult. He then labels this as a "new discovery, a new theory". The speaker speaks with a thoughtful tone.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a slide titled "FIGURE 29.22" from OpenStax, featuring a diagram that illustrates the changing estimates of the content of the universe over the past three decades. The diagram includes three pie charts representing the 1970s, 1980s, and 1990s, with labels such as "Ordinary dark matter," "Exotic dark matter," and "Dark energy." The text below the diagram explains the evolution of our understanding of the universe's composition, highlighting the diminishing importance of ordinary luminous matter over time. The scene then transitions to another slide titled "FIGURE 29.23," which presents a humorous cartoon from NASA about dark matter. The cartoon depicts a cereal box labeled "Dark Matter" with a "NEW! UNEXPLAINED MYSTERY FLAVOR!" tag, accompanied by a caption that reads, "Dark Matter: This cartoon from NASA takes a humorous look at how little we yet understand about dark matter (credit: NASA)." The video maintains a consistent background throughout, with a person visible in the bottom right corner, wearing a headset and appearing to be engaged in a presentation or lecture. The overall atmosphere is educational, with a focus on conveying complex scientific concepts in an engaging manner.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip features a single male speaker discussing the evolution of cosmological understanding across decades, mentioning "visible matter," "dark matter," and "dark energy." He is speaking in a conversational tone. This is followed by a mention of a "cartoon from NASA."

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a presentation slide titled "FIGURE 29.23" featuring a cartoon illustration of a cereal box labeled "DARK MATTER" with a "NEW!" banner and a "Mystery Flavor" tagline. The box is adorned with question marks and a yellow swirl, symbolizing the unknown nature of dark matter. The slide includes a caption that reads, "Dark Matter. This cartoon from NASA takes a humorous look at how little we yet understand about dark matter. (credit: NASA)" and the OpenStax logo is visible in the top right corner. The background is white with a yellow border on the left side. In the bottom right corner, a small inset shows a person wearing a headset, seemingly engaged in a presentation or lecture. The scene transitions to another slide titled "FIGURE 29.24," which depicts a timeline of the universe's history, starting from the Big Bang and progressing through various stages such as the formation of the first stars and galaxies, and the development of dark energy. The timeline is illustrated with a cosmic image and includes labels for significant events, such as the "Big Bang" and "Dark energy expansion." The caption below the timeline provides a brief summary of the universe's history, mentioning the Big Bang, the formation of protons, neutrons, and electrons, and the subsequent evolution of the universe. The OpenStax logo remains in the top right corner, and the inset of the person wearing a headset continues to be visible in the bottom right corner. The background of this slide is also white with a yellow border on the left side.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip begins with a male speaker adopting a humorous tone, discussing dark matter as a "mystery flavor" and suggesting that whoever solves it will win the Nobel Prize in Physics. Following the speech, there is music playing, seemingly belonging to the electronic genre.

events_list.video_caption: The video features a person seated in front of a computer screen, presenting educational content about the universe's history and expansion. Initially, the screen displays a diagram titled "FIGURE 29.24," illustrating the timeline of the universe's development, from the Big Bang to the present day, with annotations such as "Absorber light," "Quantum," and "Dark energy expansion." The person, dressed in a dark shirt, appears engaged in explaining the content, with their hands visible on the keyboard. The background is a simple, light-colored wall, and the atmosphere is that of an educational or instructional setting. The video then transitions to another diagram titled "FIGURE 29.25," which graphically represents the expansion of the universe over time, comparing the "Inflationary model" and the "Standard model." The person continues to interact with the computer, maintaining a focused demeanor. The consistent background and the person's attire suggest a continuous, uninterrupted presentation. The video effectively combines visual aids with verbal explanation to convey complex scientific concepts about the universe's evolution.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip starts with a male speaker presenting "a neat image of the history of the universe," mentioning the "afterglow light" and "the first stars," followed by the "development of galaxies" and "dark energy accelerating expansion." This is followed by music playing.

events_list.video_caption: The video features a slide titled "FIGURE 29.27" from OpenStax, which presents a graph illustrating the temperature of the universe in Kelvin (K) over time after the Big Bang, measured in seconds. The graph shows the behavior of four fundamental forces: strong nuclear force, electromagnetic force, weak nuclear force, and gravity, as they separated and took on distinctive characteristics as the universe cooled. The slide includes a caption explaining that at very early times, all four forces were indistinguishable, but as the universe cooled, they took on separate characteristics. The background of the slide is white, with the graph and text in black and blue. In the bottom right corner, there is a small inset video of a person, likely the presenter, who appears to be explaining the content of the slide. The presenter is wearing a dark-colored shirt and is gesturing with their hands while speaking. The environment suggests an educational or academic setting, possibly a classroom or lecture hall. The video maintains a consistent focus on the slide and the presenter throughout the sequence.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip starts with a single male speaker in a lecturing tone, discussing four "fundamental forces" including gravity, the weak and strong nuclear forces, and the electromagnetic force. He poses a question about which is the weakest and then answers: "it would be gravity." The audio ends with a non-speech sound, possibly a cough.

events_list.video_caption: The video features two individuals in separate settings, both wearing headphones and engaging in what appears to be a video call or recording session. The first person, dressed in a dark polo shirt with a logo, is seated in a living room adorned with various framed pictures, a couch, and a door. They are actively gesturing with their hands, suggesting they are speaking or explaining something. The second person, wearing a maroon hoodie with a large "M" logo, is in a room decorated with posters, a lamp, and a computer setup. They also gesture while speaking, and subtitles appear at the bottom of the screen, reading, "Well did you enjoy that episode of 10 minute... if so check out all the other..." indicating they are discussing a series or content related to the "10 minute" theme. The video transitions between these two individuals, maintaining a consistent focus on their upper bodies and the surrounding environments, which are both personal and casual.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a male speaker summarizing the previous segment on the Big Bang and directing listeners to the next episode. The speaker speaks with a casual, conversational tone. Then, another male speaker asks if the listener enjoyed the episode, promoting the playlist for other videos, also in a casual manner.

events_list.video_caption: In the video, a person wearing a maroon hoodie with the letter "M" and the word "Missouri" on it is seen sitting in a room filled with various decorations and posters on the walls. The individual is wearing headphones and appears to be speaking or presenting something, as indicated by their hand gestures and facial expressions. The room is illuminated by a lamp and has a cozy, personal atmosphere. On the screen, there is text that reads, "VIDEOS on my channel and then the stats updated," suggesting that the person is discussing content related to their channel and its statistics. The person points to the right side of the screen, where a button is located, and the text "Button right there" appears, indicating that viewers should click on the button. The video maintains a consistent setting and focus on the individual's presentation throughout.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a male voice encouraging viewers to watch his videos and then to hit the subscribe button. His tone is casual and friendly.  Following the man’s speech, there is silence.
